No. 28 Xianning West Road Xi'an Shaanxi Province 710049 China The selective catalytic reduction of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) by carbon monoxide (CO-SCR) is a promising way to deal with exhaust gasses. And Effective redox cycle and NO dissociation ability are crucial factors for catalytic reduction of NO x . Herein, Fe decorated CeO2 microsphere catalysts with surface oxygen defect were synthesized by solvothermal and calcination method. Among all catalysts, 0.5Fe-CeO2 sample showed excellent catalytic performance with efficiency near 96% for NO reduction under the condition of 550 ppmv NO, 1200 ppmv CO, and 40,000 h − 1 of GHSV. It was found that Fe doping could efficiently regulate Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple and oxygen vacancy for catalytic activity. XRD, Raman, XPS, EPR and H2-TPR etc. were employed to explore the physicochemical properties of samples. The results showed that Fe had been incorporated into CeO2 by XRD, and the results of Raman spectrum and XPS indicated that Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple existed in 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst. Furthermore, the H2-TPR spectrum displayed the formation of oxygen vacancy in the samples. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms indicated that the doping of Fe could enlarge the specific surface area, pore volume and pore dimeter of the samples, and thus greatly enhanced the NO adsorption and further NO catalytic reduction on catalysts. In addition, other characterization of physicochemical properties and density functional theory (DFT) calculation were performed to reveal the mechanism of NO + CO reaction. As a result, a mechanism was proposed to elucidate highly efficient NO reduction over the catalysts of Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres. Finally, the synergistic effects of redox center and oxygen vacancy on catalytic activity enhancement were revealed. This work provides a promising way to the design of efficient catalysts for NO reduction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Surface oxygen defect Redox center NO reduction Fe-doped CeO2 microsphere catalyst Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are major air pollutions from both stationary sources (industry plants, etc.) and mobile emissions (vehicle exhausts, etc.), which may pose great threats to the atmosphere, e.g., acid rain, photochemical smog, the greenhouse effect and the ozone layer depletion [1–4]. As the regulations of nitrogen oxide emission are becoming increasingly strict, it is imperative to develop promising DeNO x technology. The DeNO x technologies mainly include selective catalytic reduction (SCR), selective non-catalytic reduction (SNCR) and catalytic combustion [5–7]. For selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technologies, the reducing agent of ammonia (NH3) are widely used. However, the NH3-SCR method suffers from some drawbacks of ammonia slipping, catalyst poisoning and air heater fouling. Therefore, many researchers explore other reducing agents, such as CO [8, 9], CH4 [10, 11], H2 [12, 13] and hydrocarbon [14, 15]. Besides, in coal-fired power plants, in order to reduce NO x emissions, deep-stage low-NO x combustion technology is usually adopted. And a certain amount of CO is produced at a reducing atmosphere in the furnace. Thus, CO can be used to reduce NO to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions. In addition, catalytic reduction NO by CO is a promising technology since the reducing agent CO can be easily obtained from pyrolysis gas [3]. Selective catalytic reduction with CO (CO-SCR) technology has been investigated by more and more researchers [16–18]. The noble metal-based catalysts (Pt, Pd, and Rh et al.) have shown excellent DeNO x ability due to their high catalytic activity [19–21]. The above noble metal-based catalysts are mainly applied in exhaust fumes of vehicle engines but they cannot be applied to industry plants in a large scale. Thus, the non-noble metal catalysts are proposed to remove NO x in industry plants. Ceria oxide (CeO2) exhibits excellent catalytic performance due to its abundant oxygen vacancy, and it possesses high thermal stability and oxygen storage/release capacity (related to redox cycle of Ce3+/Ce4+) [22–24]. Bahrami et al. [9] synthesized a series of CeO2 −MO x (M = Mn, Fe and Cu) to reduce NO by CO, and the results showed the excellent reduction performance of Ce-Cu mixed oxide exhibited with 80% NO conversion. Sun et al. [25] prepared CuCeAl catalyst by stepwise impregnation for NO removal, and the CuCeAl catalyst displayed superior activity for NO reduction by CO. Besides, Bai et al. [26] employed CuO/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts to reduce low concentration NO by CO, and the reaction process followed the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. All above studies have demonstrated the CeO2 catalyst with excellent activity for NO reduction with CO, which can improve catalytic performance by further modification. In practical industrial application, there is great excess oxygen in flue gas which could react with CO, and thus hinder the NO conversion. Cheng et al. [4] exploit a rotary reactor to overcome the effect of oxygen concentration. Through this way the NO + CO reaction can be separated into NO adsorption stage and NO reduction stage without oxygen [27, 28]. Introducing oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst is one of the most efficient modification strategies to enhance the redox cycle of oxygen and thus facilitate reduction ability. Cheng et al. [4] founded that the incorporation of Fe2O3 into CeO2 could generate oxygen vacancy in catalyst system. Du et al. [3] investigated NO reduction by CO on Cu2M9CeO x catalyst. And oxygen vacancies exist in Cu2M9CeO x catalyst, which was beneficial to improve the decomposition of free NO3 − and accelerate the redox reaction. Specially, doping of transition metal is the most effective method to regulate the oxygen vacancy in catalysts [29, 30]. Wang et al. [31] founded that the Fe-doped MnO2 can generate oxygen vacancy and the total oxygen concentration can be adjusted by calcination temperature. Tong et al. [30] constructed the vacancy engineering of Fe-doped W18O49, and the catalyst exhibits high reduction ability. In this work, Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres with surface oxygen defect were successfully fabricated by solvothermal and calcination method. It was founded that the surface oxygen vacancy can be adjusted by Fe doping CeO2, which could enhance the activation of oxygen molecules to accelerate the reduction ability of catalyst. In addition, the generation of oxygen vacancy is conducive to the adsorbing of nitrogen-containing species. Furthermore, in order to evaluate the catalytic activity, the NO removal test by CO-SCR method was conducted. Based on the catalyst performance test and the sample characterization, it is proposed that an effective catalytic reaction can be achieved via tuning Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres with surface oxygen defect. This study offers a promising way for ameliorating adsorption ability of nitrogen-containing species in catalytic reaction through surface oxygen defect engineering. Experimental and computational section Materials In this work, all reagents were of analytical grade, cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3•6H2O) and ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3•9H2O) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Absolute ethanol (C2H5OH) and ethylene glycol (C2H6O2) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). And ultra-pure water was obtained from local source. Preparation of samples Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres catalysts were fabricated by a typical solvothermal and calcination process as illustrated in Scheme 1 . Concretely, 1 mmol Ce(NO3)3•6H2O was added to 80 mL C2H6O2 solution and then be magnetically stirred for 30 min. Afterwards, Fe(NO)3⋅9H2O with different molar ratios (Fe:Ce = 0.5:1, 1:1 and 2:1) were dissolved to the mixed solution. The above solution was stirred for 30 min until clear solutions was formed at room temperature. Then, the mixed solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave for solvothermal reaction at 180 °C for 12 h. The collected precipitate was washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol for three times respectively to remove impurities. Then it was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the obtained products were calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in the air at a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The above samples were denoted as 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 respectively. For comparison, the pure CeO2 was prepared in the similar way to the above synthesis process but without Fe(NO)3⋅9H2O, which was labeled as CeO2. Characterization The crystalline phase of as-prepared samples was measured by X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD, Panalytical X'Pert PRO, Netherlands), using Cu Kα radiation with a 2 theta range from 10° to 80° at a scanning rate of 2°/min. The morphology features of samples were observed at 10 kV on scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi SU8010, Japan). The microstructure of product was tested by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM, Hitachi JEM-2100F, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The particle size of catalysts was tested by Laser particle size analyzer (Zetasizer Nano ZS, England). The surface chemical valance state and chemical bonds were checked by using the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, AXIS ULTRADLD, England) with an Al Kα X-ray source radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV) at 150 W. The Raman tests were applied to investigate the chemical functional groups of catalysts on an inVia Qontor equipment. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were investigated by a spectrometer (Bruker A300, Germany). The temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) and NO-temperature programmed surface reaction (NO-TPSR) are tested in a Temperature programmed chemical adsorption instrument (AutoChem II 2920). The specific surface area and pore structure of samples were tested via Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 based on the N2 adsorption/desorption curves. The reduction features of catalyst were studied by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) with 50 mg sample. The functional groups of samples were analyzed via in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (in situ DRIFT) on a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50). Computational details All calculations were implemented by using CASTEP codes in Materials Studio (Accelrys, San Diego, CA). In calculations, the spin-polarized density functional theory plus Hubbard U term (DFT + U) method was applied [32, 33]. The exchange correlation interaction energy was carried out by using Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [34]. The electronic states were calculated via plane wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 500 eV [35, 36]. The convergence criteria of energy charge, force threshold and stress were 5 × 10−6 eV, 0.005 eV/nm and 0.02 GPa, respectively [36]. The valence electrons 5s, 5p, 6s, 5d, and 4f for Ce, and 2s and 2p for O atoms were performed in this calculation [37]. The value of U term affects the energy and valance band, thus the Ce 4f (5.0 eV) was chosen to correct coulomb U [37, 38]. The Brillouin zone integration was performed using Monkhorst-Pack schemes with a 2 × 2 × 2 k-point grids for the geometry optimization. Catalytic performance experiment The excess oxygen could react with CO and inhibit NO conversion [39, 40]. Cheng at al. reported that a rotary reactor to separate the NO removal into adsorption stage in the presence of oxygen and reduction stage without oxygen [27, 41]. Thus, in this paper, the NO reduction without oxygen was mainly investigated. The catalytic activity of catalysts was evaluated by removing NO in a fixed-bed quartz flow reactor (Inner diameter = 15 mm). The catalytic reduction evaluation system is presented in Fig 1, which consists of gas distributing system, reaction system and gas monitoring system. The total flow rate of the gas was 1.2 L/min, and the simulated flue gas was prepared by using 550 ppmv NO + 1200 ppmv CO, and balanced with N2. The corresponding gas hourly space velocity ( G H S V = q v π h r 2 of which q v means the total flow rate; h represents the height of the catalyst in the reactor and r refers to the inner radius of the reactor) is 40,000 h − 1. The test for each condition was conducted for a period of time until the experiment reaches a steady state. The concentration of NO was measured by using an on-line flue gas analyzer. Finally, the exhausted gas from the reactor was removed through the treatment system. The catalytic performance was evaluated with the catalyst (1.0 g) loaded into the reactor. The removal efficiency of NO can be calculated by the following formula (1) η N O ( % ) = N O in − N O out N O in × 100 % where NOin and NOout represent the concentration (ppmv) of NO at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. Results and discussion Catalytic performance The results of NO conversion rate for catalysts under CO-SCR reaction condition are shown in Fig 2. It can be observed that the NO conversion of CeO2 is the lowest one among all catalysts in Fig 2a. When doping with different molar ratios of Fe and Ce, the NO conversion of 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 increased sharply as the temperature rose from 250 °C to 400 °C. It was obvious that the doping of Fe on CeO2 catalyst could greatly improve the catalytic ability for NO removal. When the temperature reached 450 °C, the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst showed a high NO conversion rate near 96%. Compared to pure CeO2, the active temperature windows of 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 catalysts were broaden from 400 °C-500 °C to 250 °C-500 °C, demonstrating that doping Fe can greatly enhance the NO removal efficiency. Furthermore, the physicochemical properties of the catalyst are studied below. Crystal structure characteristic and morphology analysis XRD and Raman analysis The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were checked to identify the crystal on the CeO2, 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2, and 2Fe-CeO2 as shown in Fig 3a. For pure CeO2, it can be seen that XRD pattern matched well with the standard card of cubic fluorite structure CeO2 (JCPDS NO. 34–0394) [4, 42]. And the characteristic peaks of CeO2 samples located at 28.5°, 33.08°, 47.49°, 56.35°, 59.09°, 69.42°, 76.71° and 79.08° corresponded to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331) and (420) crystal planes, respectively. With the increase of Fe doping amount, the intensities of peak (111) and (220) planes of 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 sample were gradually decreasing, which indicated the doping of Fe into the CeO2 lattice. In addition, the plane (110) of Fe2O3 (JCPDS NO. 33–0664) were observed at 35.6° of 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 sample. When Fe was doped, the peaks of planes (222), (400), (331) and (420) gradually became lower. This phenomenon demonstrates that Fe doping can change the crystal structure of CeO2, leading to the substitution of Fe into the CeO2 lattice. And the surface oxygen vacancy may be formed due to the Fe doping, which beneficially facilitate the redox reaction in catalyst [43, 44]. The Raman spectra of all catalysts are presented in Fig 3b. An intense band can be observed at 464 cm−1, which corresponding to the F 2 g vibration mode in metal dioxides with fluorite-like structure of pure CeO2 [23, 24, 45]. After Fe doping, the band of F 2 g of CeO2 moved to lower wavenumber regions, which indicated the incorporation of Fe into CeO2. In addition, the intensity peak of F 2 g changed with the doping amount of Fe. The above analysis will be further verified by other methods. SEM, TEM and HRTEM analysis The morphology and microstructure of as-synthesized materials were characterized by SEM method in Fig 4a-e. It can be observed that the structure of CeO2 microspheres in Fig 4a is unique, which is beneficial to adsorb pollutants with microspheres structure. According to Fig 4b-d, as Fe was doped, the catalyst surface became rough, indicating the addition of Fe changed the surface structure of the CeO2 catalyst. Some small particles could be seen on the surface of microspheres, which might be caused by the doping of Fe. As the concentration of Fe doping increased, the microspheres morphology became irregular due to the fact that Fe had formed a certain accumulation on the surface of the catalysts. Besides, the EDS mapping of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was investigated to verify the doping of Fe into CeO2. As presented in Fig 4e, the EDS mapping pictures demonstrate the existing of elements of Fe, O and Ce in 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst. Therefore, TEM and HRTEM analyses were applied to further observe the microstructure of catalysts. As shown in Fig 5a-b, the micrography of the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was explored by TEM and HRTEM. It can be seen that some particles supported on the CeO2 catalyst, indicating the Fe incorporation into CeO2 from Fig 5a, and these results match well with SEM results. As shown in Fig 5b, the 0.5Fe-CeO2 sample shows spacing of lattice fringe about 0.31 nm, corresponding to the crystallographic planes (111) of CeO2 [4]. Therefore, the above results of morphology and microstructure of samples clearly demonstrate the presence of Fe in CeO2. In addition, the particle size distribution curve of all samples was presented in Fig S1. The particle size of all catalysts is located at 50∼2000 nm, which are well agreed with SEM results (grain diameter ∼ 1000 nm). It can be observed that the size distribution of CeO2 catalyst has a difference with other Fe doted CeO2 samples in Fig S1. Compared to pure CeO2, the particle size distribution of other samples shifted to the small size range. In other words, the crystal structure of samples is destroyed by Fe doping and high temperature calcination to form smaller particles. Chemical valance state and chemical bonds analysis XPS, EPR and O2-TPD analysis The detailed chemical valence states of as-prepared samples 0.5Fe-CeO2 were detected by XPS as shown in Fig 6. From the XPS survey spectra, it could be observed that Fe, Ce and O existed in 0.5Fe-CeO2, which was in agreement with XRD and EDS mapping results. The binding energies of Fe, Ce and O elements were amended by containment C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV [46], and the peak fitting was conducted via Avantage software. The high-resolution XPS of Fe 2p, Ce 3d and O 1 s exhibited their characteristic peaks and binding energies in Fig 6b-d. In Fig 6b, the Fe 2p2/3 spectra was fitted with four peaks at 710.3 eV, 712.7 eV, 715.7 eV and 718.3 eV, respectively. The peaks located at Fe 2p2/3 and Fe 2p2/1 were attributed to Fe3+ [47], indicating that Fe was doped successfully. There is a peak centered on 710.3 eV, which was assigned to Fe2+ [48]. The formation of Fe2+ on catalyst was ascribed to the electrons transfer from the oxygen vacancy to neighboring Fe3+ sites and reduced Fe3+ to Fe2+ [49], which demonstrated that the oxygen vacancy could accelerate the redox reaction in catalyst. The Ce 3d spectrum of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was fitted and showed in Fig 5c, and Ce in catalyst presented two chemical states of Ce4+ and Ce3+. The peaks of u‴, u″, u0 and v‴, v″, v0 were corresponding to Ce4+, while those of u′ and v′ were attributed to Ce3+ species [26, 50]. Due to the coexistence of Ce4+ and Ce3+, the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple in the catalyst facilitated the storage and release of oxygen and enhanced the redox capability of the catalyst [26]. In O 1 s spectrum (Fig 6d), the Oα peak centered on 529 eV ∼ 530 eV and assigned to lattice oxygen (O2−) [51]. While the Oβ peak located on 531 eV, which ascribed to chemisorbed oxygen (O2 2−, O −) on surface [52]. The peaks of Oα and Oβ were coexisted in 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst, which was attributed to the unique structure of cerium dioxide and could make it easier to form oxygen vacancies. Therefore, XPS analysis verified that Fe was successfully doped and the surface oxygen vacancies could be constructed. In order to verify the existence of oxygen vacancy in catalyst, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were carried out for CeO2 and 0.5Fe-CeO2 in Fig 6e. It could be seen that the typical signal peak at g = 1.96 and 2.03 of CeO2 and 0.5Fe-CeO2 respectively, which were corresponding to the oxygen vacancy. The reason of the oxygen vacancy formation is that the surface lattice O is prone to diffuse and overflow at high temperature [53]. To further investigate the quantification results of oxygen vacancies, the O2-chemisorption of 0.5Fe-CeO2 was carried out in Fig 6f. It can be observed that a single desorption peak was in Fig 6f, indicating that the chemically adsorbed oxygen existed at about 159.1 °C [54]. In addition, the spectrum of NO-TPSR exhibited high peak, which meaning the rich oxygen vacancies were formed in 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst. In addition, the amount of oxygen desorption of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was calculated to be 0.1534 cm3/g. NO removal mechanism based on catalysts Characterization analysis BET analysis According to the SEM results in Fig 4, the microspheres structure of samples can enhance the ability of pollutants adsorption. Thus, the BET specific surface area (S BET) and pore size of as-prepared samples were further investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms to verify the excellent pollutants adsorption with large specific surface area. And the physical properties of CeO2, 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 composite catalysts were listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig 7a, all the catalyst performed a typical type Ⅲ isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures in samples [4]. From Table 1, it can be seen that Fe doping is beneficial to increase the specific surface area of CeO2. As the amount of Fe increases, the surface area of Fe doped CeO2 catalysts gradually enlarge, and the Fe-CeO2 catalyst shows the largest specific surface area of 44.4252 m2/g among all catalysts. The large specific surface area plays a significance role in catalytic reaction. Interestingly, the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst has an enhanced catalytic performance but the S BET is not the largest one. Therefore, the surface area of Fe doped CeO2 composites could affect the catalytic activity, but it is not a decisive factor. In addition, the pore size distributions were tested by BJH method in Fig 7b. It can be observed that the pore diameter of all catalysts distributes in 2–10 nm, demonstrating the presence of mesopores structure of catalysts, which is in good agreement with N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms results. Among all catalysts, the 2Fe-CeO2 catalyst possesses the biggest pore volume and pore diameter, which indicates that the doping of Fe enlarges the pore structure of CeO2. Certainly, it can enhance the catalytic activity for NO reduction with larger pore structure. In situ DRIFTS analysis In order to obtain more information about surface chemical properties of CeO2 and 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalysts, NO adsorption in situ DRIFTS spectra were analyzed from 100 °C to 350 °C in Fig 8. For CeO2 and 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalysts, the results show similar DRIFTS spectra. It could be observed that the peak at 3610 cm−1 corresponds to the surface OH stretching, which indicates that more alkaline substance could be adsorbed on acidic OH group [55]. The band at 1560 cm−1 can be ascribed to bidentate nitrate [56]. As the temperature increases, this peak changes from 1610 cm−1 to 1560 cm−1, indicating the temperature could enhance the amount of nitrite and nitrate species in reaction. For above two catalysts, the adsorbed NO x are mainly (M-O)2 NO at 1290 and 1200 cm−1 and M-(ONNO) at 1020 cm−1 [4]. It could be speculated that Ce3+ and Ce4+ in CeO2 can provide redox centers for SCR reaction, which could greatly improve the reduction ability of NO by CO. H2-TPR analysis The redox properties of as-prepared samples were performed by temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) as shown in Fig 9. The reduction peak at 468 °C of CeO2 was observed in Fig 9, corresponding to the reduction of surface CeO2 [57, 58]. When Fe was doped, two reduction temperature peaks from 300 °C – 700 °C of 0.5Fe-CeO2, Fe-CeO2 and 2Fe-CeO2 catalysts are presented in Fig 9. It could be seen from H2-TPR spectra that the first reduction peaks of Fe decorated CeO2 catalysts gradually shifted to low temperature direction compared with pure CeO2, which was caused by the fact that the interaction between Fe and CeO2 was improved and CeO2 was easily to be reduced. The above analysis matched well with XRD results. The Fe-O-Ce structure of Fe doped CeO2 sample and a strong electron interaction between Fe and Ce were constructed successfully, which could enhance the redox cycles between Fe3+/Fe2+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ [59]. Theoretical calculation The DFT calculation was performed to further investigate the possible mechanism of doping Fe and constructing oxygen vacancy for catalytic activity enhancement. The bulk structure of CeO2, CeO2 with oxygen vacancy (CeO2 Ov), Fe-doped CeO2 and Fe-doped CeO2 with oxygen vacancy (Fe-CeO2 Ov) were shown in Fig 10. In SCR reactions, the redox property is a key factor for excellent performance of catalysts. The reactivity of SCR samples could be affected by band gap of catalysts [60]. Therefore, the band gap structure of catalysts was simulated via CASTEP codes calculation. As shown in Fig 11a-d, the energy gap of CeO2, CeO2 with oxygen vacancy, Fe-CeO2 and Fe-CeO2 with oxygen vacancy were calculated to be 1.960 eV, 0.044 eV, 1.470 eV and 0.418 eV, respectively. It could be observed that the band gap of CeO2 with oxygen vacancy (0.044 eV) was smaller than that of pure CeO2 (1.960 eV), indicating that the oxygen vacancy could efficiently improve the reactivity of SCR. In addition, the doping of Fe could also demonstrate the similar phenomenon for band gap structure. Furthermore, a comparison of the projected density of states (PDOS) for CeO2 and CeO2 with oxygen vacancy are shown in Fig 11e. Compared with pure CeO2, the O 2p orbital of CeO2 with oxygen vacancy shifts to higher energies, which indicates that the low concentration of O in CeO2 Ov and it is beneficial to catalyze CO-SCR reaction [37]. Stability and application prospect of catalysts The stability of catalysts is critical for their practical application. Among the all catalysts, the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst is regarded as the most feasible due to its excellent activity. Thus, the stability of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was tested through about 9 h simultaneous removal exam, and the results is shown in Fig 12a. It can be seen that the NO conversion rate has little degradation almost 6% within 9 h, which indicates that the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst possesses excellent stability. The XRD and XPS of 0.5Fe-CeO2 sample before and after NO removal test are also investigated to further verify the stability of catalyst in Fig 12b-c. From Fig 12b, it can be observed that the elements valence states have almost no change at all. It is worth noting that the intensity of crystal plane (110) has slightly weaken, indicating that the doping of Fe plays a significance role in NO removal reaction. In Fig 12c, the characteristic peaks of Ce 3d, Fe 2p and O 1s of used and fresh 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalysts are not significantly different. Generally speaking, it can be concluded that the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst possesses excellent stability. Reaction mechanism In order to observed reactivity of the NO x intermediates, the NO-TPSR of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst was investigated in Fig S2. It can be seen from the results that the thermal desorption process is accompanied by an obvious decomposition reaction, and the desorption products include NO, N2 and N2O. From the above experimental and theoretical analyses, the possible NO removal reaction mechanism over catalysts with CO was proposed in Scheme 2 . In SCR reactions, the NO and CO pass through the Fe-CeO2 Ov catalyst, NO was adsorbed to form nitrogen-containing species and the CO adsorbed on the active sites, which followed the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. From the in-situ DRIFTS spectra results, nitrite and nitrate species were existed in reactions, which can easily adsorb NO on surface of catalysts. The reaction of Ce3+ + Fe3+ ↔ Ce4+ + Fe2+ can accelerate the generation of oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancy can weaken the intensity of NO bond and dissociate NO to generate N and O radicals [17, 61], which greatly enhances the NO removal. Besides, the existence of oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface forms a hole with positive charge, which is conducive to providing a site for promoting the reaction with electrons and free O to form superoxide species, and further improve the reduction reaction of NO by CO. CO could react with O radicals to form CO2, and the residual N radicals combine with NO to generate N2O. In addition, contact reaction of N radicals and O radicals can generate N2 or O2. To sum up, the synergistic effect of redox centers (Ce3+/Ce4+) and oxygen vacancies greatly improve the catalytic activity for CO + NO reaction. And the main reactions process can be described as following Eqs. (2-8): (2) Fe-CeO2 + calcination → Fe-CeO2 (Ov) (3) NOa (Ov) → Na + Oa (4) COa + Oa → CO2 (5) NOa + Na → N2Oa (6) N2Oa → N2O (7) N2Oa → N2 + Oa (8) Na + Na →N2 Conclusions In conclusion, Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres with surface oxygen defect was successfully synthesized via solvothermal and calcination method. From the experimental analysis, the results demonstrated that the 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst showed high catalytic activity for CO-SCR with NO conversion rate near 96%, which was superior to pure CeO2. In the SCR reactions, Fe can activate neighboring oxygen molecules to enhance the reactivity. As the concentration of doped Fe increased, the NO removal efficiency of samples decreased, which was because of the inhibition of the reduction active centers by Fe. Based on physicochemical property and theoretical analyses, it is found that the doping of Fe can effectively regulate the Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple and oxygen vacancy for catalytic activity. The oxygen vacancy can facilitate the reduction ability of CO for NO. In addition, the band gap structure of catalysts can be modulated by introducing oxygen vacancy. The synergistic effect of the doping of Fe and oxygen vacancy brings the higher catalytic activity of 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst to NO conversion. This work provides a promising approach to design SCR catalyst, and offers a novel method for pollutants removal in energy and environmental restoration. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic reduction of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) by carbon monoxide (CO-SCR) is a promising way to deal with exhaust gasses. And Effective redox cycle and NO dissociation ability are crucial factors for catalytic reduction of NO x . Herein, Fe decorated CeO2 microsphere catalysts with surface oxygen defect were synthesized by solvothermal and calcination method. Among all catalysts, 0.5Fe-CeO2 sample showed excellent catalytic performance with efficiency near 96% for NO reduction under the condition of 550 ppmv NO, 1200 ppmv CO, and 40,000 h − 1 of GHSV. It was found that Fe doping could efficiently regulate Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple and oxygen vacancy for catalytic activity. XRD, Raman, XPS, EPR and H2-TPR etc. were employed to explore the physicochemical properties of samples. The results showed that Fe had been incorporated into CeO2 by XRD, and the results of Raman spectrum and XPS indicated that Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couple existed in 0.5Fe-CeO2 catalyst. Furthermore, the H2-TPR spectrum displayed the formation of oxygen vacancy in the samples. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms indicated that the doping of Fe could enlarge the specific surface area, pore volume and pore dimeter of the samples, and thus greatly enhanced the NO adsorption and further NO catalytic reduction on catalysts. In addition, other characterization of physicochemical properties and density functional theory (DFT) calculation were performed to reveal the mechanism of NO + CO reaction. As a result, a mechanism was proposed to elucidate highly efficient NO reduction over the catalysts of Fe decorated CeO2 microspheres. Finally, the synergistic effects of redox center and oxygen vacancy on catalytic activity enhancement were revealed. This work provides a promising way to the design of efficient catalysts for NO reduction.
coredata.dc:title: Fe decorated CeO2 microsphere catalyst with surface oxygen defect for NO reduction by CO
